1.government: Switzerland practices direct democracy, allowing citizens to vote on laws directly. https://facts.net/society-and-social-sciences/society/40-facts-about-government/
1.math: Forty is the only number whose letters are in alphabetical order. https://whizz.com/blog/20-cool-facts-maths/
1.science: Bananas are slightly radioactive due to their potassium content. https://www.rd.com/list/science-facts-never-learned/
1.history: Napoleon was once attacked by bunnies during a rabbit hunt gone wrong. https://bestlifeonline.com/historical-facts/
1.technology: The first computer mouse was made of wood, invented in 1964. https://www.tech21century.com/interesting-fun-facts-about-technology/
1.geography: Mount Everest grows about 4 millimeters each year due to tectonic uplift. https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/mount-everest-growth
1.art: Michelangelo painted the Sistine Chapel ceiling over four years using a unique fresco technique. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Michelangelo
1.movies_and_tv: The movie 'Avatar' was the first film to gross over $2 billion worldwide. https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt0499549
1.music: The world's largest grand piano was built by a 15-year-old in New Zealand in 2010. https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/largest-grand-piano
1.gaming: The term 'Easter egg' in gaming originated from a hidden credit in the 1979 Atari 2600 game 'Adventure.' https://www.atariage.com/2600/archives/Adventure
1.random: Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood. https://www.nationalgeographic.com/animals/invertebrates/facts/common-octopus

2.government: Congress consists of the Senate and House of Representatives. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress
2.science: Photosynthesis allows plants to create energy from sunlight. https://education.nationalgeographic.org/resource/photosynthesis/
2.history: Cleopatra wasn’t Egyptian—she was Greek, descended from Ptolemy. https://www.thefactsite.com/100-history-facts/
2.technology: The first webcam monitored a coffee pot at Cambridge University. https://randomfunfactsonline.com/interesting-it-facts-about-technology/
2.geography: Canada has the longest coastline of any country, stretching over 202,080 kilometers. https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/countries-with-the-most-coastline.html
2.art: The Mona Lisa has no eyebrows; it was common in the Renaissance for women to shave them off. https://www.louvre.fr/en/explore/the-palace/mona-lisa
2.movies_and_tv: The series finale of M*A*S*H in 1983 drew over 105 million viewers, the highest for any US TV episode. https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/mash-series-finale
2.music: Beethoven continued to compose music even after he became completely deaf. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Ludwig-van-Beethoven
2.gaming: Minecraft began as a solo project by Markus Persson and was first released in 2009. https://www.minecraft.net/en-us/article/minecraft-10-year-anniversary
2.random: A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance.' https://www.nationalgeographic.com/animals/birds/facts/flamingo

3.government: Estonia offers online voting, making it one of the most digitally advanced democracies. https://facts.net/society-and-social-sciences/society/40-facts-about-government/
3.math: A jiffy is a real unit of time, equal to 1/100th of a second. https://www.mathnasium.com/math-centers/hinsdale/news/10-math-facts-you-did-not-know
3.science: Lightning is hotter than the surface of the sun, reaching about 30,000 Kelvin. https://www.zmescience.com/feature-post/resources/metascience/10-quick-scientific-facts-will-blow-mind/
3.history: Stagecoach Mary was the first Black female U.S. postal worker and carried a rifle for protection. https://allthatsinteresting.com/history-facts
3.technology: The first text message ever sent said "Merry Christmas" in 1992. https://randomfunfactsonline.com/interesting-it-facts-about-technology/
3.geography: There are more than 2,000 distinct types of cacti found primarily in the Americas. https://www.britannica.com/plant/cactus
3.art: Salvador Dalí designed the melting 'soft watch' for the 1945 film 'Dreams That Money Can Buy.' https://www.theartstory.org/artist/dali-salvador/
3.movies_and_tv: 'Gone with the Wind' (1939) won 10 Academy Awards, a record at the time. https://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1939
3.music: The 'Amen break' is a 6-second drum solo from the song 'Amen, Brother' by The Winstons, sampled extensively across genres. https://www.bbc.com/culture/article/20160115-the-10-samples-that-changed-music
3.gaming: The PlayStation was originally conceived as a joint project between Nintendo and Sony. https://www.ign.com/articles/2008/03/25/the-creation-of-the-playstation-trilogy
3.random: Honey never spoils; edible honey was found in ancient Egyptian tombs. https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/why-honey-doesnt-spoil

4.government: Canada’s written constitution wasn’t patriated until 1982, almost a century after Confederation. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_Act,_1982
4.math: Zero is the only number that cannot be represented in Roman numerals. https://www.mathsisfun.com/roman-numerals.html
4.science: Venus rotates in the opposite direction of most planets, making its day longer than its year. https://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/venus/overview/
4.history: Oxford University began teaching around 1096—more than 150 years before the Aztec civilization was founded. https://www.ox.ac.uk/about/organisation/history
4.technology: The first 1 GB hard drive, introduced by IBM in 1980, weighed over 500 pounds and cost $40 000. https://www.ibm.com/ibm/history/exhibits/storage/storage_4506.html
4.geography: Russia spans 11 time zones, the most of any country on Earth. https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/which-country-has-the-most-time-zones.html
4.art: Leonardo da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa on a poplar wood panel rather than canvas. https://www.louvre.fr/en/explore/the-palace/mona-lisa
4.movies_and_tv: The Wizard of Oz (1939) was the first Hollywood film broadcast on television in 1956. https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0032138
4.music: Jingle Bells became the first song ever broadcast from space, relayed by astronauts in 1965. https://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/imagegallery/image_feature_1954.html
4.gaming: The longest continuous Minecraft play marathon lasted 1760 hours (over 73 days). https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/longest-marathon-playing-a-sandbox-video-game
4.random: A single day on Venus (243 Earth days) is longer than its year (225 Earth days). https://www.nasa.gov/venus

5.government: Bhutan uses Gross National Happiness—measuring well-being and sustainability—instead of GDP. https://www.grossnationalhappiness.com/
5.math: A googol is 10^100, a number far greater than the estimated atoms in the observable universe. https://mathigon.org/course/number-alpha
5.science: Sharks have existed for around 400 million years, predating trees by over 50 million years. https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/sharks-tour-60075140/
5.history: Cleopatra lived closer in time to the first Moon landing (1969) than to the construction of the Great Pyramid (c. 2560 BC). https://www.history.com/news/cleopatra-facts
5.technology: There are more active mobile phone subscriptions globally than there are toothbrushes. https://www.zdnet.com/article/one-in-five-people-dont-own-a-toothbrush/
5.geography: Antarctica is the only continent without any native reptiles or snakes. https://www.antarctica.gov.au/about-antarctica/wildlife/
5.art: Salvador Dalí’s melting clocks in The Persistence of Memory were reportedly inspired by seeing Camembert cheese soften in the sun. https://www.moma.org/collection/works/79018
5.movies_and_tv: Toy Story (1995) was the first feature-length film made entirely with computer-generated imagery. https://www.pixar.com/feature-films/toy-story
5.music: The world’s largest theremin orchestra comprised 65 performers in Austria, 2019. https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/largest-theremin-ensemble
5.gaming: Minecraft holds the record as the best-selling video game of all time, with over 240 million copies sold. https://www.minecraft.net/en-us/article/minecraft-10-year-anniversary
5.random: Wombat droppings are cube-shaped, preventing them from rolling away on sloped terrain. https://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20150323-why-pure-cubes-come-out-of-wombats
